theory.concept: When to Use Lists, Tuples, Sets, or Dictionaries
theory.introduction: Different data structures solve different problems. Choosing the right one makes your code cleaner, faster, and more readable.
theory.explanation: Use lists when you need an ordered, changeable sequence. Use tuples for fixed collections. Use dictionaries to map keys to values. Use sets when uniqueness matters.
keyPoints: üìã Use lists for ordered, editable sequences
üîê Use tuples for read-only or fixed data
‚öôÔ∏è Use sets for uniqueness and fast membership tests

codeExamples.explanation: Use list to hold a group of items
Use dictionary to store labeled data
Use set to store unique IDs

importantNotes: ‚ùå Avoid using lists for lookups (use dict or set instead)
‚úÖ Know if you need order, mutability, or keys
üß† A good structure makes your code easier to debug

task.description:
1. Store a fixed pair of coordinates (5, 10) as a tuple
2. Store unique class roll numbers: 101, 102, 101 in a set
3. Store a product's name and price in a dictionary
Then print all three structures.
